clean_story: Two voices.  One harmony. "Simon & Garfunkel" was the stage name for Paul Simon and Art Garfunkel, a duo whose songs sounded like a single voice split in two. Most heard their music as effortless—like sunlight through leaves. But their sound came from tension. Simon wrote lyrics sharp as a knife,  while Garfunkel’s voice wrapped around them like silk. They met in 1953 as kids singing "doo-wop" under a staircase at school. By 1964, they recorded The Sound of Silence—a song about loneliness that became an anthem for millions. Fun fact: The track was first released quietly, then re-mixed with drums and electric guitar without their input. That version turned it into a #1 hit. Their albums—Bridge Over Troubled Water, Parsley, Sage, Rosemary and Thyme—sold over 100 million copies. Yet by 1970, they split. Too different. Simon craved control; Garfunkel acted in films like Catch-22. Three related subjects are folk music’s protest roots, studio production tricks, and why duos break up.
